item.description: long long开小了，血的教训。 Solution It’s quite obvious that $a$ and $b$ must be coprime. Now let’s prime factorize $X$ and there will be at most 11 distinct primes since the product of the first 12 primes is greater than $1\cdot 10^{12}$. To find the answer we can simply distribute them between $a$ and $b$ with bruteforce. item.title: Editorial of Codeforces 1334E - Divisor Paths
item.description: 看了N遍dls的讲题终于明白了 Solution First let’s factor $D$, so $D=p_1^{e_1}p_2^{e_2}\dots p_k^{e_k}$. According to the definition, to factors are connected iff they differ by only one prime factor. And the weight of the edge is $d(x)-d(y)$ where $d(i)$ is the number of factors of $i$. So the length of a path where $v_1<v_2<\dots<v_k$ is $d(v_k)-d(v_i)$ There are only two types of paths between $x$ and $y$, one is $x \rightarrow\gcd(x,y)\rightarrow y$ and the other is $x \rightarrow \operatorname{lcm}(x,y) \rightarrow y$.
